al wore

We are

text:
EHILIP MORRISCQMEANIESJNC:
WTER-QEEICE CQRBESPONDENCE
120 PAAK AVENUE, NEWYOAK
NY 10017-5592
To
AlI Philip Morris Employees
DATE:
January 2, 1996
FRom:
Steven C. Parrish
SUBJECT:
EDA Updatelndustry News Conference
As yoU may be aware, today was the final
to submit comments to the Food
and Drug Administration (FDA) regarding the agency's plan to regulate the
marketing and s2le of cigarettes
The agency received hundreds of tnousands
of comments
majority of which opposed the FDA's proposed regulations:
Today in Washington
we at Philip Morris joined The Tobacco Institute and
other members cfthe tobacco industry afa news conference, during which we
made
public our comments to the FDA
Speaking on behalf of tne industry,
restated the industry's commitment to
preventing minors from having access to cigarettes_
also outlined the
numerous reasons
we believe the FDA's plan to regulate cigarettes is
illega
and excessive
The FDA's proposal is not really about preventing youth
smoking_
FDA seeks to ban common promotiona
practices and impose
requirements tha
would interfere wvith adults' choices and the rights of
cigarette
companies to sell a legal product
A complete copy of my remarks from today's
news conference is attached_
would like to express senior managements heartfelt thanks to each of
wt:o
took tne time t0 contact the FDA on this most imporant issue
specia
thank
you to those who went the extra mile by asking friends; family members and
business contacts to take action.
The FDA is required by law to catalogue and
evaluate each and every letter received
We will pursue efforts in the courts to prevent the FDA from seizing regulatory
control of our products
We !vill keep you informed as developments occur, and
will also continue to let you know how YOU can most eifectively help to oppose
the FDA's plan_
Thank you again, and happy New Year to all_
attachment
day
why
you
1

SUBJECT:

Attzched is
Preventing Teenage Accoss to Tobacco, the final report presented to the
Attorneys General of the Tobacco Ratailer Responsibility Initiative (TRRI)
project
endorsed by
National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG)-
TRRI's mission is to provlde assistance to AGs in proactive measures to prevent the sale cf
tobacco products to mincrs_
Its focus has been the application of consumer protection
authority as a tool to prevent tobacco saies to minors_
The report provides historical backgrourd, activities on tobacco-rclated issues, and
suggestcd activites for AGs, most of which we have already heard about
Following is & brief review of chapters 3-7 and a list of Appendices:
Applicatlon of Consumer Protcctlon Authority: Recommends the use of consumer
protection laws as a means to enforce violations of the minimum age sales law.
In addition to
ttese laws providing greater penalties than the state sales to minors law,
it allows AGs t0
address the responsibility of the storeowner rather than the actions of one individual salcs
clerk.
The report Cescribes tne expansion of the application of this authority since it was
started in 1987 with a private act.on, Kyte V.
Store 24,followed by actions in Massachusetts
(1994and
995); Kansas
996); New York{MassachusettsNermont
1998) (i.8._
Assurances
of Discontinuance); and prcmulgation of rules by thc Massachusetts AG
998)-
Enforcement Issues_
Building Alliances in Tobacco Enforcement Suggests that AGs
fomm ailiarces with govemment agencies
the public health sector
and tho FDA to participate
in tobacco enforcement efforts_
These alliances would be especially helpful in those siates
that do rot enforce the Iaw in conjunction with
sales detected
during Synar and FDA
inspections_
Additionally; AGs may be able to use the results of FDA and Synar Inspections
to bring consumer protection actions whan sales to minors meet certain criteria of state
statutes Or rules
report also notes that the MSA would appear to provide AGs with
resources to Inltiate these actions against retailers when #t can be documented through
